markdownRemark.html:
Let's talk about the Bayesian classifier in detail today. At the end, you can decide if it is the best classifier!

Let's say we have a two dimensional feature space, with feature vectors [x,y]. We also have the training set that is labeled. The label consists of two classes, blue and red.

Here is your task: I give you a feature vector, can you tell me which class this feature vector belongs to? I also want to know the decision boundary you used to determine the class. Is this a simple task?

In other words, would you classify the grey point below as class blue or class red?

In this post, you are going to learn:

  • Bayesian classifiers - best classifier in the world?
  • Discriminant function - how to calculate the decision surfaces?
  • Linear vs quatric decision surfaces - what is the difference?

Bayesian classifiers

I asked a friend who knows nothing about classifiers to tell me which class the gray point belongs to. He said it looks like it belongs to class red due to how each class "centers" and the "spread." Then he said he basically compares the standard deviations. Little did he know, what he described is exactly the intuition behind the Bayesian classifier.

Bayesian classification is a form of probabilistic classification. Intuitively, when determining a line that separates the two classes, we look at the distribution of each class. What my friend intuitively focused on was the "center" or the mean and the "spread" or the standard deviation of the distribution. Another factor can be the prior of each class. For example, if there are more blue class to begin with, then we can think that blue class is more probable and the line would shift away from the blue class. Ok, now let's put these ideas into a more mathematically rigorous form.

Giving a feature vector xxx, we want to find the most probable class. Given MMM classes [w1,w2,...wM][w_1, w_2, ... w_M][w1​,w2​,...wM​], if P(wi∣x)>P(wj∣x)P(w_i|x) > P(w_j|x)P(wi​∣x)>P(wj​∣x), then xxx belongs to class wiw_iwi​, and wjw_jwj​ the other way around. Notice that this is a two class problem, but it can be generalized easily with multiple classes. So the question is how do we find P(wi∣x)P(w_i|x)P(wi​∣x) ?

Bayes rule

P(wi∣x)=P(x∣wi)P(wi)P(x)P(w_i|x) = {P(x|w_i)P(w_i) \over P(x)}P(wi​∣x)=P(x)P(x∣wi​)P(wi​)​

Bayes rule tells me that if I want to estimate P(wi∣x)P(w_i|x)P(wi​∣x), then I need to know P(x∣wi)P(x|w_i)P(x∣wi​) and P(wi)P(w_i)P(wi​). P(x∣wi)P(x|w_i)P(x∣wi​) is the conditional pdf or the distribution of possible features when they belong to wiw_iwi​. It can be estimated from the training data. P(wi)P(w_i)P(wi​) is the prior, which is know. For example, if we had equal number of blue and red classes in our training data, then the prior for each class would be 0.5. So back to our original question, is the probability of xxx being in wiw_iwi​ less or greater than in wjw_jwj​?

= P(wi∣x)<or>P(wj∣x)P(w_i|x) < or > P(w_j|x)P(wi​∣x)<or>P(wj​∣x) ?

= P(x∣wi)P(wi)P(x)<or>P(x∣wj)P(wj)P(x){P(x|w_i)P(w_i) \over P(x)} < or > {P(x|w_j)P(w_j) \over P(x)}P(x)P(x∣wi​)P(wi​)​<or>P(x)P(x∣wj​)P(wj​)​ ?

= P(x∣wi)P(wi)<or>P(x∣wj)P(wj)P(x|w_i)P(w_i) < or > P(x|w_j)P(w_j)P(x∣wi​)P(wi​)<or>P(x∣wj​)P(wj​) ?

The question above partitions the feature space into two. One is when the probability of being in wiw_iwi​ is greater than wjw_jwj​ and the other is when the probability of wjw_jwj​ is greater than wiw_iwi​. So where is the line that separates the two?

It is exactly where P(x∣wi)P(wi)=P(x∣wj)P(wj)P(x|w_i)P(w_i) = P(x|w_j)P(w_j)P(x∣wi​)P(wi​)=P(x∣wj​)P(wj​)

or where P(x∣wi)P(wi)−P(x∣wj)P(wj)=0P(x|w_i)P(w_i) - P(x|w_j)P(w_j) = 0P(x∣wi​)P(wi​)−P(x∣wj​)P(wj​)=0
